summary: This document is a Know Your Customer (KYC) record for Jeffrey Epstein, detailing his financial relationships, account ownership, and associated individuals. It includes information about the Butterfly Trust, which Epstein is connected to as a grantor, and outlines the roles of various trustees and beneficiaries. The document also highlights the financial institutions involved and the expected inflows and outflows for Epstein's accounts. This document appears to be a Know Your Customer (KYC) form related to account management at Deutsche Bank, detailing compliance checks and comments from various professionals involved in the account's oversight. It includes references to trust agreements and beneficiary changes, indicating a focus on financial due diligence.

connections.description: Stewart Oldfield manages the banking relationship for Jeffrey Epstein at Deutsche Bank.
Harry Beier serves as a trustee for the Butterfly Trust established by Jeffrey Epstein.
Erika Kellerhals is a trustee of the Butterfly Trust, working alongside Jeffrey Epstein.
Both Harry Beier and Erika Kellerhals are trustees managing the Butterfly Trust.

locations: 6100 Red Hook Quarter, St. Thomas, USVI
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein is the grantor of the Butterfly Trust, which is being managed by trustees Harry Beier and Erika Kellerhals.
The Butterfly Trust accounts at Deutsche Bank include a checking account and a money market account, both opened on 10/09/2013.
The expected volume of assets for the Butterfly Trust is projected to be $15,000,000 one year after opening.
The document includes details about the financial inflows and outflows for Epstein's accounts, with estimates ranging from $1,000 to $20,000 per transaction.
There are no negative media mentions related to Jeffrey Epstein in the context of this KYC record, although previous court cases are acknowledged.
The document is a KYC form related to account management at Deutsche Bank.
Cynthia Rodriguez made multiple comments regarding the trust agreement and beneficiary changes.
Jason Shames provided advice on the necessary forms for beneficiary changes.
Armen Brash and other staff members signed off on the document, indicating their involvement in the account's oversight.
The document emphasizes the importance of due diligence and compliance in managing client relationships.
